name: Titanium.Platform
doc:
@platform android 0.8 @platform blackberry 3.1.2 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @platform mobileweb 1.8 @editurl https://github.com/appcelerator/titanium_mobile/edit/master/apidoc/Titanium/Platform/Platform.yml

The top-level Platform module. The Platform module is used to access the device's platform-related functionality.

Examples

Battery Event Example

Obtaining battery data when the battery state changes.

Titanium.Platform.addEventListener('battery', function(e){
  Ti.API.info('The battery state has changed to ' + e.state);
  Ti.API.info('The battery level is ' + e.level);
  Ti.API.info('The battery event source is ' + e.source);
  Ti.API.info('The battery event name ' + e.type);
});

property.name: BATTERY_STATE_CHARGING
property.doc: Constant to indicate that the system is plugged in and currently being charged.

property.name: BATTERY_STATE_FULL
property.doc:
Constant to indicate that the battery is fully charged.

@description

On Mobile Web, BATTERY_STATE_FULL is defined, but will never be a valid state.
property.shortDoc: Constant to indicate that the battery is fully charged. ...

property.name: BATTERY_STATE_UNKNOWN
property.doc: Constant to indicate that the battery state is not known or monitoring is disabled.

property.name: BATTERY_STATE_UNPLUGGED
property.doc: Constant to indicate that the system is unplugged.

property.name: address
property.doc:
System's WIFI IP address. No other network types are supported.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: apiName
property.doc:
The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to.

@description

The value of this property is the fully qualified name of the API. For example, Button returns Ti.UI.Button.

@platform android 3.2.0 @platform blackberry 3.2.0 @platform iphone 3.2.0 @platform ipad 3.2.0 @platform mobileweb 3.2.0
property.shortDoc: The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to. ...

property.name: architecture
property.doc:
System's processor architecture.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: availableMemory
property.doc:
System's unused memory, measured in megabytes on iOS and bytes on Android.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8
property.shortDoc: System's unused memory, measured in megabytes on iOS and bytes on Android. ...

property.name: batteryLevel
property.doc: Battery level in percent, accessible only when batteryMonitoring is enabled. Measured in 5% increments on iPhone/iPad.
property.shortDoc: Battery level in percent, accessible only when batteryMonitoring is enabled. ...

property.name: batteryMonitoring
property.doc:
Determines whether battery monitoring is enabled.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @platform mobileweb 1.8
property.shortDoc: Determines whether battery monitoring is enabled. ...

property.name: batteryState
property.doc:
Indicates the state of the battery. Accessible only when batteryMonitoring is enabled.

@description

On Mobile Web, battery state will either be charging, unplugged, or unknown. Full charge state is not supported.

This API can be assigned the following constants:

  • BATTERY_STATE_CHARGING
  • BATTERY_STATE_FULL
  • BATTERY_STATE_UNKNOWN
  • BATTERY_STATE_UNPLUGGED
property.shortDoc: Indicates the state of the battery. ...

property.name: bubbleParent
property.doc:
Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent.

@description

Some proxies (most commonly views) have a relationship to other proxies, often established by the add() method. For example, for a button added to a window, a click event on the button would bubble up to the window. Other common parents are table sections to their rows, table views to their sections, and scrollable views to their views. Set this property to false to disable the bubbling to the proxy's parent.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0
property.shortDoc: Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent. ...

property.name: displayCaps
property.doc:
Returns the DisplayCaps object.

@description

Note that the displayCaps property begins with a lowercase letter, which differentiates it from the DisplayCaps object that it returns.

property.name: id
property.doc:
Applications's globally-unique ID (UUID).

@description

On Android, this may be the UDID (unique device ID). For iOS, this is a unique identifier for this install of the application.

Previously on iOS this may have been a UDID, but access to this has been restricted by Apple. For more information, see Apple's uniqueIdentifier documentation.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @platform mobileweb 1.8

property.name: lifecycleContainer
property.doc:
The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy.

@description

If this property is set to a Window or TabGroup, then the corresponding Activity lifecycle event callbacks will also be called on the proxy. Proxies that require the activity lifecycle will need this property set to the appropriate containing Window or TabGroup.

@platform android 3.6.0
property.shortDoc: The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy. ...

property.name: locale
property.doc:
System's default language.

@description

Locale, as a combination of ISO 2-letter language and country codes. For example, en-US or en-GB. See the ISO 639-1 and ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 sections of wikipedia for reference.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @platform mobileweb 1.8

property.name: macaddress
property.doc:
System's network interface mac address, or app UUID.

@description

On iOS, this value is the app's UUID. Apple does not allow access to any hardware identifier information as it can be used for unique device identification, which they have prohibited.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8
property.shortDoc: System's network interface mac address, or app UUID. ...

property.name: manufacturer
property.doc:
Manufacturer of the device.

@description

Returns the manufacturer of the device, for example, motorola. Virtual devices return unknown.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0

property.name: model
property.doc:
Model of the device.

@description

An identifier of the hardware model of the device. For example, HTC Sensation Z710e.

Virtual devices will also return a value. For example, sdk for the standard Android SDK and google_sdk for the enhanced Android Google APIs SDK running in an emulator, and Simulator for iOS running in a simulator.

Mobile Web will return the browser Agent information, such as Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:12.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/12.0 for Firefox 12 running on Ubuntu.

Examples

Testing for a Virtual Device

Determine whether the application is running on a virtual device.
    if (Ti.Platform.model === 'Simulator' || Ti.Platform.model.indexOf('sdk') !== -1 ){
      alert('Accelerometer does not work on a virtual device');
    } else {
      // Add Accelerometer event listener
    }

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: name
property.doc: Name of the platform. Returns android for the Android platform, iPhone OS for the iOS platform (iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch), and mobileweb for the Mobile Web platform.

property.name: netmask
property.doc:
System's WIFI network mask. No other network types are supported.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: osname
property.doc: Short name of the system's Operating System. Returns android for the Android platfrom, iphone for the iPhone or iPod Touch, ipad for the iPad, and mobileweb for the Mobile Web platform.
property.shortDoc: Short name of the system's Operating System. ...

property.name: ostype
property.doc:
Operating System architecture. On Android, this is 32bit.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @platform mobileweb 1.8

property.name: processorCount
property.doc:
Number of processing cores.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: runtime
property.doc:
Short name of the JavaScript runtime in use.

@description

On iOS this is "javascriptcore", on Android either "v8" or "rhino" and on Mobile Web it is determined by the browser used.
property.shortDoc: Short name of the JavaScript runtime in use. ...

property.name: username
property.doc:
System name, if set. On iOS, this can be found in Settings > General > About > Name.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: version
property.doc: System's OS version.

method.name: addEventListener
method.doc: Adds the specified callback as an event listener for the named event.

params.name: callback
params.doc: Callback function to invoke when the event is fired.

method.shortDoc: Adds the specified callback as an event listener for the named event. ...

method.name: applyProperties
method.doc:
Applies the properties to the proxy.

@description

Properties are supplied as a dictionary. Each key-value pair in the object is applied to the proxy such that myproxy[key] = value.

params.name: props
params.doc:
A dictionary of properties to apply.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform blackberry 3.3.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0 @platform mobileweb 3.0.0

method.shortDoc: Applies the properties to the proxy. ...

method.name: canOpenURL
method.doc:
Returns whether the system is configured with a default application to handle the URL's protocol.

@description

On Mobile Web, this method always returns true, even if the browser can't open the specific URL, unless the URL is empty or undefined.
method.shortDoc: Returns whether the system is configured with a default application to handle the URL's protocol. ...

method.name: is24HourTimeFormat
method.doc:
Returns whether the system settings are configured to show times in 24-hour format.

@description

On Mobile Web, this function always returns false.
method.shortDoc: Returns whether the system settings are configured to show times in 24-hour format. ...

method.name: openURL
method.doc: Opens this URL using the system's default application for its protocol.

method.name: removeEventListener
method.doc:
Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event.

@description

Multiple listeners can be registered for the same event, so the callback parameter is used to determine which listener to remove.

When adding a listener, you must save a reference to the callback function in order to remove the listener later:

var listener = function() { Ti.API.info("Event listener called."); }
window.addEventListener('click', listener);

To remove the listener, pass in a reference to the callback function:

window.removeEventListener('click', listener);

params.name: callback
params.doc: Callback function to remove. Must be the same function passed to addEventListener.

method.shortDoc: Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event. ...

event.name: battery
event.doc: Fired when the battery state changes. This is measured in 5% increments on iPhone/iPad.

params.name: state
params.doc:
The battery state.

This API can be assigned the following constants:

  • BATTERY_STATE_CHARGING
  • BATTERY_STATE_FULL
  • BATTERY_STATE_UNKNOWN
  • BATTERY_STATE_UNPLUGGED

(android iphone ipad) source

Source object that fired the event.

(android iphone ipad) type

Name of the event fired.

(android iphone ipad) bubbles

True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

(android iphone ipad) cancelBubble

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

event.shortDoc: Fired when the battery state changes. ...
